repnme.cdata!:
Broadening the evaluation of rural
            development projects : final report on the Lilongwe land
            development program follow up study

abstracts.cdata!:
This report presents the findings and
            conclusions arising from the analysis carried out in the
            Lilongwe Land Development Program (LLDP) follow-up study
            RP0-293. The study objectives are to assess the usefulness
            of a range of data collected by the LLDP Evaluation Unit for
            the purpose of evaluating the impact of the project. In
            particular, attention is focused on the ability of the data
            to reveal what has happened art Lilongwe, by a search for
            project benefits which might be quantified in the data, and
            to reveal why changes have occurred, by attempting to assess
            the effectiveness of various project components, credit and
            the extension service.

docna.cdata!:
Malawi - Lilongne Agricultural Development
            Project : Credit 0113  - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Malawi - Lilongne Agricultural
            Development Project : Credit 0113  - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed credit consists of the
            partial financing of a first 4-year phase, involving 163,000
            acres, of a 13-year integrated agricultural improvement
            program ultimately covering 500,000 acres near Lilongwe. The
            aim of the program is to raise the present production of
            maize and groundnuts while maintaining the output of
            tobacco. The growth in production will be achieved by
            increasing yields per acre and by making effective use of
            all suitable land. Yield increases are expected to result
            from the application of fertilizers, together with improved
            cultivation and weeding practices. The introduction of these
            techniques through extension will be supported by the
            closely integrated development of rural infrastructure, the
            provision of supervised farm credit service, reorganization
            of holdings and registration of titles to land. About
            one-third of the proposed credit would be directed towards
            the financing of extension staff.
